transcription.text: Glass Cinema lantern slide with black edging tape and internal black frame. This hand coloured slide is an advertisement for the film 'Under the Clock' featuring Judy Garland by Metro Goldwyn Mayer Ltd. A piece of light brown tape has been adhered to the top edge of the image to cover session times.

Cyberpunk and anime aesthetics mix with a climate apocalypse in Umurangi Generation, a Māori sci-fi, first-person photography game inspired by the 2019 Black Summer bushfires. Not only does it draw on developer Naphtali Faulkner’s experience as a photographer but the government response to Black Summer – in Te Reo, Umurangi means ‘red sky’, a reference to the hellish atmosphere during the catastrophe. In the game’s futuristic Tauranga, neon lights illuminate rooftops and condemned housing districts, the walled-city streets bustle with partygoers and fighter jets fly overhead. Through the camera’s viewfinder, the player is given an intimate view of a city suffering through climate change, political apathy and over policing. By giving players the ability to change lenses and minutely edit images, they’re given a sense of agency over the chaos, with points earned for creatively capturing the environment rather than shooting enemies like most dystopian games.

In 1948, Australian audiences were introduced to television at the Sydney Royal Easter Show. The British electronics company Pye had brought its 405-line cameras and monitors to encourage interest in the new medium.

While it would be eight years until Bruce Gyngell famously welcomed Australia to television, the Pye company was still essential to the burgeoning industry.

Pye cameras like this were used across Australia in newsrooms and in the field by journalists at GTV9 and ABV2. They are lightweight and compact, making them easy to transport, and they feature an extended focus range switch for extreme close-ups.

work.title: Type 2014K Image Orthicon camera
work.creator_credit: Films & Equipment Ltd., PYE Ltd. and Vinten

transcription.text: Console with power cable purchased on ebay February 2020

Television didn’t just change the way we see the world; it changed the look and layout of our homes. Since TV arrived in Australia in the 1950s, how and where we watch TV evolved alongside its form and function. These six miniature dioramas, designed by Graham McGuffie and handmade by Emily Boutard, reflect how home interiors changed to make way for TV across different decades, representing the common places people watched their favourite stories unfold on-screen.

From the 1930s, people could go on 3D adventures with characters like the Lone Ranger and Davy Crockett thanks to the Tru-Vue stereoscopic viewer. Strips of 35mm film featuring 14 stereo images were fed into the Tru-Vue, and a lever advanced the film and story. When held up to the light, the images appeared in 3D.

In 1951, Tru-Vue merged with the popular View-Master system, which used circular colour reels that brought tourist attractions and travel images to life in 3D. Some of the most popular View-Master reels included virtual tours of the newly built Disneyland, as well as stories featuring Mickey Mouse, Peter Pan and other popular Disney characters.
A compliation of moments from various 'home movies' in the ACMI Collection.

TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. A response to her video dancing to country song ‘International Harvester’ suggested she “probably [didn’t] know how to start a tractor”. Well, she proved him wrong and gained over 3.4m views in four days. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag. A play on ‘yall and alternative, the movement provides an online space for leftist, LGBTQIA+ and goth folk living in rural areas.

Toy Lantern. Two toy slides (system ID 179286) were donated with the lantern.
Made by George Carette & Co. Nuremberg
